headline: Hillary Clinton rages against President Trump in commencement speech
subHeadline: Former Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton gets political at New York's Hunter College; reaction and analysis on 'The Five.'

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello, everybody. I'm Jesse Watters, along with Katie, Juan, Dana, and Greg. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is “The Five.” President Trump fired up and tearing into Robert Mueller, the president ripping the former special counsel to shreds after his first public comments on the Russia probe.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT
utterances.sentences: It was to me the same as the report. There's no obstruction. There's no collusion. There's no nothing. It's nothing but a witch hunt. This is a witch hunt by the media and the Democrats, they're partners. I think he's totally conflicted. I think Mueller is a true never-Trump-eer. He's somebody that dislike Donald Trump. He's somebody that didn't get a job that he requested that he wanted very badly and he was appointed.  And despite that, and despite $40 million, 18 Trump haters including people that work for Hillary Clinton and some of the worst human beings on earth, they got nothing. It's pretty amazing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Trump's blistering condemnation of Mueller comes as Democrats and the media are ramping up their impeachment push.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: To impeach or not to impeach? That is the question now confronts House Democrats.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Prepare for impeachment that's what I told my colleagues.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The Democratic control Congress will have no choice but to open an impeachment inquiry into President Trump.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I believe that the president obstructed justice and I would vote to impeach.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Act now or lose our democracy forever, and the only method that we can do that is for our representatives in Congress to begin impeachment proceedings.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It sounds like the special counsel is calling for Congress to pick up where he left off. That process has a name, it begins with the letter I, Impeachment.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Trump shooting down all the impeachment talk, though.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I don't see how they can, because they're possibly allowed. Although, I can't imagine the courts allowing it. To me, it's a dirty word, the word impeach. It's a dirty, filthy, disgusting word, and it had nothing to do with me. So I don't think so, because there was no crime. You know, it's a high crime and, not with or, or, it's high crimes and misdemeanors. There was no high crime and there was no misdemeanor. How do you impeach based on that. The whole thing is a scam. It's a giant presidential harassment.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Greg, tell everybody why you're laughing so hard.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST
utterances.sentences: Don Lemon, he's so funny. It begins with the letter I, and you figure it ends there, and he goes impeachment. Oh, Jesus. I thought it was something else.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.sentences: Investment.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, my God, the drama. This is so much fun. It is so much fun. You know, here's a long analogy, let's say you and your spouse have plans to go see her in-laws, right? But she gets a cold and can't go, that's the opportunity when you can fake how badly you wanted to go even though you didn't want to go. You go, but I wanted to see your parents. That's what impeachment is for the Democrats.  This is an opportunity for them to say how badly they want it knowing it's not going to happen, because it's not going to happen. So all the small Democrats, the Swalwell's and the Beto's of the world, they can play the theater of really, really wanting it and getting attention, but it's really not going to happen.   By the way, so this really isn't Trump's problem, it's a Democratic Party problem.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, definitely.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right now -- you guys see Poseidon Adventure?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There's a point in Poseidon Adventure where the survivors are deciding which direction to go in the capsized boat, and so they're arguing and then one group leaves and they all die. If they listen to the media, if the Democrats listen to the media they're gonna go the wrong way on the boat.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Impeachment, and they're all gonna perish underwater.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Not one of your best analogies --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I thought it was beautiful, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No one has ever seen that movie.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The in-laws one --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The in-laws one was great.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And, Dana, I was reading Axios this morning. And to Greg's point, they only did a whip count and found 20 to 30 House Democrats that are supporting impeachment right now. That's not a lot.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And I think that -- that's why I think that the media coverage of impeachment is way overblown compared to what people really want. And also remember, House Speaker Nick Pelosi is speaker now because moderate Democrats won in swing district, 31 of them, and she's holding the line. Like, she will not be speaker if those people don't win again.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Hold the line, Nancy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The other thing is -- I think that the question that I would want to ask Mueller, if when did you know that you -- when did you make the decision that you could not indict? And if you had that early on, wouldn't some sort of a smoke signal have been helpful? Because now, unfortunately, I think that it's all muddled.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I think he's using that as an excuse because he came to that conclusion after the fact.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I don't think so --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I also ask him, when did you know there was no collusion? Did you know it before the midterms? But that's why he doesn't want to face Congress or the media because he doesn't want to answer those questions.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He just wants people to read his report.

utterances.speaker: KATIE PAVLICH, HOST
utterances.sentences: To pick up on Dana's question about when he knew about not being able to indict, the Justice Department in partnership with the special counsel last night released a joint statement after all of this confusion about the discrepancy between indicting, not indicting, what's allowed under the OLC rules, and it seems like based on the statement they released that there was an agreement almost from the beginning about the fact that you can't indict the president, but that does not preclude you from going and looking and investigating and finding may be co-conspirators or other people that you can indict on other crimes. But based on that statement it seems like there was an agreement very early on that they were on the same page when it came to what the Justice Department regulations said you could do in terms of indicting a sitting president. But on that note, going back to the media, it's like have they not learned their lesson about how they handled these kinds of stories? I mean, they're going to get President Trump reelected.   There's a huge risk for Democrats here, not only in losing the House for Nancy Pelosi, but also the political blow back. If they're going to push this so hard in the primary and just drop it off in the general election, it shows that they're not willing to do what they actually said they were going to do, which is the politician speak that everybody is trying to get away from.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, Juan, you weren't here yesterday, so I will let you take the floor.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, HOST
utterances.sentences: You know. I'm just reacting to what I saw today, and what I saw today is the president going after Robert Mueller. So I'm thinking to myself, wait, he can't have it both ways. In one juncture he says no collusion, right, no obstruction of justice, according to the Mueller report. Now he comes out and he says, that Mueller, so prejudice, so much a witch hunt, he hates me, he had a bad business deal with me. You can't trust that guy. He's got all the Hillary Clinton --.   You say, wait a second, you a minute ago were citing this man's work, now you're condemning this man. I think you've got a problem, Mr. President. I think you are being contradictory, hypocritical, and it's just like you go off and you attack everybody. And you know, you said something a moment ago, you said, oh, no evidence of any kind of conspiracy. That's not what Mueller said. Mueller said insufficient.  And I think this comes back to the fact that so many people were misled by Bob Barr. But even more than that, I noticed today, the reaction from conservative suggests to me that they never read the Mueller report because if they had, they would have known everything that Mueller said yesterday. It's in the report.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, if the media is saying the president is a criminal, and he's colluding, and there's a grand conspiracy between himself and the president of Russia, and the special counsel comes back and says there's insufficient evidence to charge anybody with a crime related to conspiracy, isn't that just legally is for no collusion?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know what? I mean, literally, there are -- I think it's a thousand former prosecutors who says, with regards to obstruction of justice, if this guy wasn't president, he would have been charged --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: We could go out right now and find a thousand other lawyers who say the other thing. I think one of the problems is that the law is vague. The law is -- I mean, the Congress, if you want to have a more clear law, then past one.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Insufficient evidence that I kidnap the Lindbergh baby. It doesn't matter. Insufficient evidence, if that's the end -- by the way, can I use another literary analogy?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Please.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: OK. The media are like the sirens in the odyssey, right? They're luring sailors to their death. In this case, the media is luring the media -- I mean, luring the Democrats to their death by telling them to impeach. And if the Democrats listen to the media, they're going to end up on the rock, 2020 Trump.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Let me use an analogy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think a lot of conservatives are like Donald Trump in Japan hiding the USS McCain, keeping it out of pictures because I don't want a picture --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Fake news.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know what? He's trying to hide from the reality of what he did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Maybe shut that fake news story down. You know what? We've got to go, bad analogy. Next, Hillary Clinton delivers what may be the worst commencement address of all time, the low lights will show you next. And later, it's the big day for us on The Five, our good friend John Rich is here and he's going to be performing our song, shut up about politics.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Well, the class of 2019 may have gotten an unexpected torture session from Hillary Clinton, the failed twice Democratic nominee, using her commencement speech at New York's Hunter College to get political, attacking President Trump, the Russia probe, and more, watch.

utterances.speaker: HILLARY CLINTON, FORMER PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: Our democracy feels far from secure. They banned Muslims from entering the country. And our government is tearing children from the arms of their parents at the border and locking them in cages. Make no mistake. We are witnessing an assault on the rule of law and the foundation of our democracy. What do we do when people in positions of authority are not held accountable? When they defy request from the Congress? When Facebook refused to take down a fake video of Nancy Pelosi, it wasn't even a close call, the video is sexist trash.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: So, Greg, Hillary was so brave that she wanted to go after President Trump for 30 minutes but didn't say his name.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Every time she speaks you're reminded how different and irrelevant the typical kind of political oratory has become. It's like when you're listening to her, you just go like -- I think the media is lying that they would have preferred that over Trump, because Trump has made politics interesting for once, she's just old and tired and I mean that, listening to her not as a person. Trump is a gift. He's actually made -- brought peace and prosperity, while delivering volatility in his own personality. So you get the volatility but you get the success and the achievement so you can still enjoy his personality and not feel bad. By the way, she's speaking -- she was asked to speak at a cybersecurity symposium.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's like asking -- I don't know, Michael Moore to speak at weight watchers. It makes no sense at all and I can't wait to hear that speech.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: I want to know how much they're paying her. She's speaking at -- she's keynoting the fire-ice cyber defense summit with the world's leading cyber experts. Maybe they can teach her something about that. But, Dana - -

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And they're paying her.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yeah, lots of money, like a half million dollars, right? I mean, come on. But, Dana, you've given advice to graduates before, isn't it really unfair that Hillary Clinton would take away this moment from them, their achievements, to talk about herself?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right. Like, so if I was in the audience like I'd might say, oh, gosh, I don't feel very inspired right now. However, a little research, like the graduates that were there they liked it. So I think that --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They're brainwashed.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They are.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: How about this, they're interested in --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Their professors tell them what to think. That's how they get their grades. Come on, we know. We know.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know what? You're just unhappy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm having a great time. I'm having a great time.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Mr. Cranky would prefer if those are the clowns is in the White House --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Wait, you're running?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think we have the real one. But I mean seriously, the graduates prefer someone, I think, who would have taken away all of their student debt, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Santa Claus.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Robert Smith.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, they would have preferred that. But I don't think there's any question that they're interested in current affairs, they're smart people, they're graduating with a degree, and they want to know what's going on. And you talk about somebody who knows what's going on, it's Hillary Clinton. And to talk about cybersecurity, she may be the greatest victim of cyber security.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Oh, come on, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You think there's any doubt the Russians put their finger on the scale to help --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Hillary Clinton should give a speech at the cybersecurity summit about how to start an illegal server from your basement or your bathroom and how to delete hard drives. I mean, there's a lot she could teach people.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I wish Trump would give a speech about how we are protecting America against more Russian interference.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think he's been harder on Russia than any president.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, here's how you do it. You don't have some guy hand over the password -- it's password to the hacker, like John Podesta did to Hillary Clinton. Juan, this speech was so bad I don't even think the graduates threw their hats up in the air. They were all falling asleep. And, Dana, I would have to disagree, on Watters' World this weekend, we had a family that was so disgusted with the speech, she went off the rail, he was upset because he paid all of these money to have the daughter go to Hunter College, and she gets up there and totally humiliates herself.  He's angry, tune it at 8 o'clock Eastern. And then you know what? She can't read a room either. This is supposed to be inspiring and uplifting, and no one wants to hear --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It was about her. It was about her.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It was about her. And I want to know how much she got paid, because Hunter College, I'd do it for half that price.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I like how you make the phone sign, you know, because they still use the phone.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: But, Greg, isn't this the point that, you know, you pay to go to college and then you pay these massive amounts of speaker fees while these students have all these loans, and they're trying to get into the real world, and yet it's hijacked by someone who wants to talk about herself and issues that really are unrelated to --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't see it as hijacking. I think this is completely -- it's exactly what -- it's what they want.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: A parent who's paid like thousands -- hundreds of thousands of dollars for your kid to get a degree, and you listen to that --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What I'm saying is, this has been going on for decades, they have liberal commencement speakers. They have liberal administration. It's just one big liberal love fest. When I see this, it's like -- it's kind of like -- again, you know, it's like being surprised when you find garbage at the dump.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, also, a lot of commencement speakers, and you didn't see it as much this year, but in 2016 in particular, you saw a lot of commencement speakers use it as a chance to make news. It's not like the purpose -- was like, oh, OK. What can you do to get on cable news? And she gives a speech.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Here's my theory on why she's still staying in the game like this, she thought the insurance policy against Trump would kick in, he would get impeached, and then she would run in 2020 as the rightful heir to the throne, because she was robbed and then she would restore the Clinton dynasty. That's what --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: She kept her server on a throne.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I must say, I'm amazed you guys don't say lock her up, because I think that you're still hating on Hillary.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But I must tell you, those graduates and their parents, they're going to always remember who spoke at that graduation and they're terrifically honored as we heard --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I also remember my appendicitis.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You just love hating on Hillary. It's an indication there's something wrong here.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: OK. Up next, a foul ball scare at a baseball game raising new concerns about safety protocols. And later, country star John Rich joins us for a very special live performance you don't want to miss.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, boy, it was a terrifying night at the ballpark, Cubs outfielder Albert Almora Jr. breaking down in tears after his line drive hit a young fan in the stands during yesterday's game. The little girl was rushed to the hospital, she's reportedly doing OK. Almora, though, reacting to the scare afterwards.

utterances.speaker: ALBERT ALMORA JR., BASEBALL PLAYER
utterances.sentences: As soon as I hit it, the first person I locked eyes on was her. I'm speechless. I'm at a loss of words. Being a father, two boys.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The incident renewing calls from fans and players for more safety precautions at major league baseball games.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Let's just put fences up around the whole field. I mean, it's so sad when you see stuff like that happen. There's a lot of kids come to the games, young kids want to watch us play. I think any safety measure we can take to, you know, make sure that fans are safe, we should do it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Katie, you were at the ball game in Washington over the weekend with your pup.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yep.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It just strikes me that they put up extra netting over the last few years that cover behind the dugouts to try to protect, but you can't protect everyone all the time.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yeah. And I mean, you know, the solution to this might be having kids wearing more protective gear when they're going to the game, helmets for example would be may be an option. You don't want to take away from the atmosphere of the game either. So if they fence everything in, it kind of takes away from being at the game and feeling like you can be and in it rather than just watching it on television. And the netting, you know, is a good idea, but it's also prevents you from really engaging with the players. So it is balanced, but obviously when something like that happens it's horrible and awful and people have been killed as a result of these things before. So you kind of have to balance out the risk. But I think when you're talking to parents whose kids get hit with a foul ball, there's not really a lot of room in the middle for negotiation.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Really. So, Jesse, you know, I think there's a very low probability that anybody is going to get hit by a foul ball at the game, and kids are actually excited to catch a foul ball.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right. Maybe they should bring their gloves and their helmets like Katie said, but I couldn't even watch this, it makes you feel sick to your stomach. So they should just give this family free tickets for life. That's the only way to solve it. I don't know what you can do about these things, freak accidents happen in life. I'm a freak accident, people have to accept me. There's nothing you can do about it. Other sports there's risk too, golf, someone slices one half of the tee you get hit in the shoulder, I've seen that thousands of times. Or about boxing, sometimes stuff spill out of the ring and there's a melee and someone gets a chair through the mouth. It happens a lot, and that's part of what happens when you go to a live sporting event. Baseball it does happen more than other sports, though. But they've already extended the netting, almost every single team has done that. Perhaps you can extend it more, and I'm willing to have that debate. But you can't have some sort of missile defense system where they can knock out a fly ball or a foul ball the minute it hits the bat. You just have to live with these things. And it's sad, but that's life.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Man, it's a tough one. You know, Dana, one of the things that struck me was that Albert Almora Jr. had such an emotional reaction as a player.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I think -- as he said, because he's a father as well. And he also -- he said that he locked eyes with her, so he knew it was going to happen. I do think that in hockey, they extended the protection for people --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: NBA playoffs.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yeah, but it happened a long time ago, but it was because people kept getting hit in the head --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I mean, NASCAR, too. You have like car parts flying all over the infield or the outfield.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And the thing about MLB, as it's called, Major League Baseball, is that they're trying to figure out a way how do we keep people coming to the game and watching on TV? And so, if extending the netting is something that will keep people coming, because I think that was a good point. People want to bring their families there. You want to take your kids because it's a great American past time.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It is. Greg, I will tell you a funny story.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Several years back when I was at the Orioles with my wife, and she's a character. So we're sitting there and a foul ball comes screaming in and it bounces into this kid.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And the father sitting next to the kid protects himself, not the kid. Now this is -- remember they have a camera on us, right? Elise jump up and start berating the father as a chicken and a jerk for not protecting the kid. I was like, man, what about the kid.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But from an evolutionary standpoint, the father was protecting himself knowing that he would be important later in life for the child.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know what? I'll let you get hit by the ball, because later I've got to pay for your college education and the speech by Hillary Clinton, which is why Trump needs to be impeached? Guess I'm not worked up about this, am I an awful person?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm not an awful person for saying that. The odds of this happening are so low. It's why you take the risk. You assume the risk when you enter the stadium. You have a greater chance of a fatal car accident on the way to the game than getting fatally beamed by a ball. And like you said, every time this happens in a lot of sports, there's a lot of other interesting stories about sports that we should be covering.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Like, I was researching this topic for the show, 2014 Statistical Analysis by Bloomberg, said that approximately 1,700 fans per year are injured at major league baseball.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Wow, by what though, did they say?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It didn't say. It didn't go that deep into the survey. But, I mean, baseball - you get hit by a foul ball, I mean, does happen.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, it does.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But I don't go.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I actually am afraid, because I am always talking, I am not paying attention. I'm afraid.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, no.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But you are a tiny target.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So was the kid.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, you're smaller.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, no. And besides you would be, as you told me, in a box.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, you would be in a box. Yes, exactly, surrounded by --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: --the box.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: --your entourage would take the hits. They would dive in front, the ball would hit him in the face, then you just hire another intern--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: --for your dirty, dirty world.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Stop now.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know what, Greg, more people are hurt by the Poseidon Adventure.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That is true.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God, the drama. This is so much fun. It is so much fun. You know, here's a long analogy, let's say you and your spouse have plans to go see her in-laws, right? But she gets a cold and can't go, that's the opportunity when you can fake how badly you wanted to go even though you didn't want to go. You go, but I wanted to see your parents. That's what impeachment is for the Democrats. This is an opportunity for them to say how badly they want it knowing it's not going to happen, because it's not going to happen. So all the small Democrats, the Swalwell's and the Beto's of the world, they can play the theater of really, really wanting it and getting attention, but it's really not going to happen. By the way, so this really isn't Trump's problem, it's a Democratic Party problem.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, definitely.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right now -- you guys see Poseidon Adventure?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There's a point in Poseidon Adventure where the survivors are deciding which direction to go in the capsized boat, and so they're arguing and then one group leaves and they all die. If they listen to the media, if the Democrats listen to the media they're gonna go the wrong way on the boat.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Impeachment, and they're all gonna perish underwater.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not one of your best analogies --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I thought it was beautiful, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No one has ever seen that movie.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The in-laws one --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The in-laws one was great.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And, Dana, I was reading Axios this morning. And to Greg's point, they only did a whip count and found 20 to 30 House Democrats that are supporting impeachment right now. That's not a lot.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And I think that -- that's why I think that the media coverage of impeachment is way overblown compared to what people really want. And also remember, House Speaker Nick Pelosi is speaker now because moderate Democrats won in swing district, 31 of them, and she's holding the line. Like, she will not be speaker if those people don't win again.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Hold the line, Nancy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The other thing is -- I think that the question that I would want to ask Mueller, if when did you know that you -- when did you make the decision that you could not indict? And if you had that early on, wouldn't some sort of a smoke signal have been helpful? Because now, unfortunately, I think that it's all muddled.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think he's using that as an excuse because he came to that conclusion after the fact.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't think so --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I also ask him, when did you know there was no collusion? Did you know it before the midterms? But that's why he doesn't want to face Congress or the media because he doesn't want to answer those questions.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He just wants people to read his report.

utterances.speaker: KATIE PAVLICH, HOST
utterances.utterance: To pick up on Dana's question about when he knew about not being able to indict, the Justice Department in partnership with the special counsel last night released a joint statement after all of this confusion about the discrepancy between indicting, not indicting, what's allowed under the OLC rules, and it seems like based on the statement they released that there was an agreement almost from the beginning about the fact that you can't indict the president, but that does not preclude you from going and looking and investigating and finding may be co-conspirators or other people that you can indict on other crimes. But based on that statement it seems like there was an agreement very early on that they were on the same page when it came to what the Justice Department regulations said you could do in terms of indicting a sitting president. But on that note, going back to the media, it's like have they not learned their lesson about how they handled these kinds of stories? I mean, they're going to get President Trump reelected. There's a huge risk for Democrats here, not only in losing the House for Nancy Pelosi, but also the political blow back. If they're going to push this so hard in the primary and just drop it off in the general election, it shows that they're not willing to do what they actually said they were going to do, which is the politician speak that everybody is trying to get away from.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, Juan, you weren't here yesterday, so I will let you take the floor.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, HOST
utterances.utterance: You know. I'm just reacting to what I saw today, and what I saw today is the president going after Robert Mueller. So I'm thinking to myself, wait, he can't have it both ways. In one juncture he says no collusion, right, no obstruction of justice, according to the Mueller report. Now he comes out and he says, that Mueller, so prejudice, so much a witch hunt, he hates me, he had a bad business deal with me. You can't trust that guy. He's got all the Hillary Clinton --. You say, wait a second, you a minute ago were citing this man's work, now you're condemning this man. I think you've got a problem, Mr. President. I think you are being contradictory, hypocritical, and it's just like you go off and you attack everybody. And you know, you said something a moment ago, you said, oh, no evidence of any kind of conspiracy. That's not what Mueller said. Mueller said insufficient. And I think this comes back to the fact that so many people were misled by Bob Barr. But even more than that, I noticed today, the reaction from conservative suggests to me that they never read the Mueller report because if they had, they would have known everything that Mueller said yesterday. It's in the report.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, if the media is saying the president is a criminal, and he's colluding, and there's a grand conspiracy between himself and the president of Russia, and the special counsel comes back and says there's insufficient evidence to charge anybody with a crime related to conspiracy, isn't that just legally is for no collusion?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what? I mean, literally, there are -- I think it's a thousand former prosecutors who says, with regards to obstruction of justice, if this guy wasn't president, he would have been charged --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We could go out right now and find a thousand other lawyers who say the other thing. I think one of the problems is that the law is vague. The law is -- I mean, the Congress, if you want to have a more clear law, then past one.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Insufficient evidence that I kidnap the Lindbergh baby. It doesn't matter. Insufficient evidence, if that's the end -- by the way, can I use another literary analogy?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Please.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK. The media are like the sirens in the odyssey, right? They're luring sailors to their death. In this case, the media is luring the media -- I mean, luring the Democrats to their death by telling them to impeach. And if the Democrats listen to the media, they're going to end up on the rock, 2020 Trump.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me use an analogy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think a lot of conservatives are like Donald Trump in Japan hiding the USS McCain, keeping it out of pictures because I don't want a picture --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Fake news.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what? He's trying to hide from the reality of what he did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Maybe shut that fake news story down. You know what? We've got to go, bad analogy. Next, Hillary Clinton delivers what may be the worst commencement address of all time, the low lights will show you next. And later, it's the big day for us on The Five, our good friend John Rich is here and he's going to be performing our song, shut up about politics.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well, the class of 2019 may have gotten an unexpected torture session from Hillary Clinton, the failed twice Democratic nominee, using her commencement speech at New York's Hunter College to get political, attacking President Trump, the Russia probe, and more, watch.

utterances.speaker: HILLARY CLINTON, FORMER PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: Our democracy feels far from secure. They banned Muslims from entering the country. And our government is tearing children from the arms of their parents at the border and locking them in cages. Make no mistake. We are witnessing an assault on the rule of law and the foundation of our democracy. What do we do when people in positions of authority are not held accountable? When they defy request from the Congress? When Facebook refused to take down a fake video of Nancy Pelosi, it wasn't even a close call, the video is sexist trash.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So, Greg, Hillary was so brave that she wanted to go after President Trump for 30 minutes but didn't say his name.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Every time she speaks you're reminded how different and irrelevant the typical kind of political oratory has become. It's like when you're listening to her, you just go like -- I think the media is lying that they would have preferred that over Trump, because Trump has made politics interesting for once, she's just old and tired and I mean that, listening to her not as a person. Trump is a gift. He's actually made -- brought peace and prosperity, while delivering volatility in his own personality. So you get the volatility but you get the success and the achievement so you can still enjoy his personality and not feel bad. By the way, she's speaking -- she was asked to speak at a cybersecurity symposium.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's like asking -- I don't know, Michael Moore to speak at weight watchers. It makes no sense at all and I can't wait to hear that speech.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I want to know how much they're paying her. She's speaking at -- she's keynoting the fire-ice cyber defense summit with the world's leading cyber experts. Maybe they can teach her something about that. But, Dana - -

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And they're paying her.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yeah, lots of money, like a half million dollars, right? I mean, come on. But, Dana, you've given advice to graduates before, isn't it really unfair that Hillary Clinton would take away this moment from them, their achievements, to talk about herself?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right. Like, so if I was in the audience like I'd might say, oh, gosh, I don't feel very inspired right now. However, a little research, like the graduates that were there they liked it. So I think that --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They're brainwashed.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They are.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: How about this, they're interested in --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Their professors tell them what to think. That's how they get their grades. Come on, we know. We know.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what? You're just unhappy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm having a great time. I'm having a great time.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Mr. Cranky would prefer if those are the clowns is in the White House --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wait, you're running?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think we have the real one. But I mean seriously, the graduates prefer someone, I think, who would have taken away all of their student debt, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Santa Claus.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Robert Smith.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, they would have preferred that. But I don't think there's any question that they're interested in current affairs, they're smart people, they're graduating with a degree, and they want to know what's going on. And you talk about somebody who knows what's going on, it's Hillary Clinton. And to talk about cybersecurity, she may be the greatest victim of cyber security.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Oh, come on, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You think there's any doubt the Russians put their finger on the scale to help --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Hillary Clinton should give a speech at the cybersecurity summit about how to start an illegal server from your basement or your bathroom and how to delete hard drives. I mean, there's a lot she could teach people.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I wish Trump would give a speech about how we are protecting America against more Russian interference.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think he's been harder on Russia than any president.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, here's how you do it. You don't have some guy hand over the password -- it's password to the hacker, like John Podesta did to Hillary Clinton. Juan, this speech was so bad I don't even think the graduates threw their hats up in the air. They were all falling asleep. And, Dana, I would have to disagree, on Watters' World this weekend, we had a family that was so disgusted with the speech, she went off the rail, he was upset because he paid all of these money to have the daughter go to Hunter College, and she gets up there and totally humiliates herself. He's angry, tune it at 8 o'clock Eastern. And then you know what? She can't read a room either. This is supposed to be inspiring and uplifting, and no one wants to hear --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It was about her. It was about her.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It was about her. And I want to know how much she got paid, because Hunter College, I'd do it for half that price.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I like how you make the phone sign, you know, because they still use the phone.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: But, Greg, isn't this the point that, you know, you pay to go to college and then you pay these massive amounts of speaker fees while these students have all these loans, and they're trying to get into the real world, and yet it's hijacked by someone who wants to talk about herself and issues that really are unrelated to --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't see it as hijacking. I think this is completely -- it's exactly what -- it's what they want.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: A parent who's paid like thousands -- hundreds of thousands of dollars for your kid to get a degree, and you listen to that --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What I'm saying is, this has been going on for decades, they have liberal commencement speakers. They have liberal administration. It's just one big liberal love fest. When I see this, it's like -- it's kind of like -- again, you know, it's like being surprised when you find garbage at the dump.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, also, a lot of commencement speakers, and you didn't see it as much this year, but in 2016 in particular, you saw a lot of commencement speakers use it as a chance to make news. It's not like the purpose -- was like, oh, OK. What can you do to get on cable news? And she gives a speech.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Here's my theory on why she's still staying in the game like this, she thought the insurance policy against Trump would kick in, he would get impeached, and then she would run in 2020 as the rightful heir to the throne, because she was robbed and then she would restore the Clinton dynasty. That's what --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: She kept her server on a throne.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I must say, I'm amazed you guys don't say lock her up, because I think that you're still hating on Hillary.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I must tell you, those graduates and their parents, they're going to always remember who spoke at that graduation and they're terrifically honored as we heard --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I also remember my appendicitis.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You just love hating on Hillary. It's an indication there's something wrong here.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: OK. Up next, a foul ball scare at a baseball game raising new concerns about safety protocols. And later, country star John Rich joins us for a very special live performance you don't want to miss.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, boy, it was a terrifying night at the ballpark, Cubs outfielder Albert Almora Jr. breaking down in tears after his line drive hit a young fan in the stands during yesterday's game. The little girl was rushed to the hospital, she's reportedly doing OK. Almora, though, reacting to the scare afterwards.

utterances.speaker: ALBERT ALMORA JR., BASEBALL PLAYER
utterances.utterance: As soon as I hit it, the first person I locked eyes on was her. I'm speechless. I'm at a loss of words. Being a father, two boys.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The incident renewing calls from fans and players for more safety precautions at major league baseball games.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Let's just put fences up around the whole field. I mean, it's so sad when you see stuff like that happen. There's a lot of kids come to the games, young kids want to watch us play. I think any safety measure we can take to, you know, make sure that fans are safe, we should do it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Katie, you were at the ball game in Washington over the weekend with your pup.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yep.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It just strikes me that they put up extra netting over the last few years that cover behind the dugouts to try to protect, but you can't protect everyone all the time.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yeah. And I mean, you know, the solution to this might be having kids wearing more protective gear when they're going to the game, helmets for example would be may be an option. You don't want to take away from the atmosphere of the game either. So if they fence everything in, it kind of takes away from being at the game and feeling like you can be and in it rather than just watching it on television. And the netting, you know, is a good idea, but it's also prevents you from really engaging with the players. So it is balanced, but obviously when something like that happens it's horrible and awful and people have been killed as a result of these things before. So you kind of have to balance out the risk. But I think when you're talking to parents whose kids get hit with a foul ball, there's not really a lot of room in the middle for negotiation.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Really. So, Jesse, you know, I think there's a very low probability that anybody is going to get hit by a foul ball at the game, and kids are actually excited to catch a foul ball.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. Maybe they should bring their gloves and their helmets like Katie said, but I couldn't even watch this, it makes you feel sick to your stomach. So they should just give this family free tickets for life. That's the only way to solve it. I don't know what you can do about these things, freak accidents happen in life. I'm a freak accident, people have to accept me. There's nothing you can do about it. Other sports there's risk too, golf, someone slices one half of the tee you get hit in the shoulder, I've seen that thousands of times. Or about boxing, sometimes stuff spill out of the ring and there's a melee and someone gets a chair through the mouth. It happens a lot, and that's part of what happens when you go to a live sporting event. Baseball it does happen more than other sports, though. But they've already extended the netting, almost every single team has done that. Perhaps you can extend it more, and I'm willing to have that debate. But you can't have some sort of missile defense system where they can knock out a fly ball or a foul ball the minute it hits the bat. You just have to live with these things. And it's sad, but that's life.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Man, it's a tough one. You know, Dana, one of the things that struck me was that Albert Almora Jr. had such an emotional reaction as a player.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I think -- as he said, because he's a father as well. And he also -- he said that he locked eyes with her, so he knew it was going to happen. I do think that in hockey, they extended the protection for people --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: NBA playoffs.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah, but it happened a long time ago, but it was because people kept getting hit in the head --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I mean, NASCAR, too. You have like car parts flying all over the infield or the outfield.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And the thing about MLB, as it's called, Major League Baseball, is that they're trying to figure out a way how do we keep people coming to the game and watching on TV? And so, if extending the netting is something that will keep people coming, because I think that was a good point. People want to bring their families there. You want to take your kids because it's a great American past time.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It is. Greg, I will tell you a funny story.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Sure.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Several years back when I was at the Orioles with my wife, and she's a character. So we're sitting there and a foul ball comes screaming in and it bounces into this kid.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And the father sitting next to the kid protects himself, not the kid. Now this is -- remember they have a camera on us, right? Elise jump up and start berating the father as a chicken and a jerk for not protecting the kid. I was like, man, what about the kid.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But from an evolutionary standpoint, the father was protecting himself knowing that he would be important later in life for the child.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what? I'll let you get hit by the ball, because later I've got to pay for your college education and the speech by Hillary Clinton, which is why Trump needs to be impeached? Guess I'm not worked up about this, am I an awful person?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm not an awful person for saying that. The odds of this happening are so low. It's why you take the risk. You assume the risk when you enter the stadium. You have a greater chance of a fatal car accident on the way to the game than getting fatally beamed by a ball. And like you said, every time this happens in a lot of sports, there's a lot of other interesting stories about sports that we should be covering.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Like, I was researching this topic for the show, 2014 Statistical Analysis by Bloomberg, said that approximately 1,700 fans per year are injured at major league baseball.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wow, by what though, did they say?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It didn't say. It didn't go that deep into the survey. But, I mean, baseball - you get hit by a foul ball, I mean, does happen.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, it does.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But I don't go.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I actually am afraid, because I am always talking, I am not paying attention. I'm afraid.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But you are a tiny target.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So was the kid.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, you're smaller.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no. And besides you would be, as you told me, in a box.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, you would be in a box. Yes, exactly, surrounded by --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: --the box.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: --your entourage would take the hits. They would dive in front, the ball would hit him in the face, then you just hire another intern--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: --for your dirty, dirty world.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Stop now.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what, Greg, more people are hurt by the Poseidon Adventure.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That is true.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: A data is in, Twitter is making you dumber. The new details ahead right here on THE FIVE. Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Whoever thought going on Twitter does you more harm than good, now there's scientific proof. A new study shows Twitter is eroding your intelligence. Researchers say indulging in hashtags likes and retweets on the popular social media platform actually has a detrimental effect on learning. This comes as no surprise to you, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, now I know I want to be Pro Twitter when this study has come out, because I know this study probably wasn't well done. However, I don't think it makes you dumber. And I'd say - I'm a broken record. It just accentuates the lesser parts of you. So if you're vain, you're more vain on Twitter, if you're insecure and you're needy and you're looking for attention then that's accentuated. Every weakness that you have is accentuated. I don't have any weaknesses, therefore on Twitter I'm pretty good. I say before, everybody that I like, I like less on Twitter.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Fair. Is that why you told Jesse to get off Twitter?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I could. I was like I really need this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He couldn't afford to like me any less.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I find that I like being pointed to articles that I might not have otherwise found--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: --my own.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You're good schemer.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think that helps, then it's a good way to look for breaking news. But I do - I can kind of understand, it's like the first thing you're always scrolling for the new thing, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, it's like speed dating like you got to go deeper, OK. You can't just scroll headlines. You're not absorbing anything. You got it like take someone out to dinner, meet them, spend a little more time.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Stop, stop. Stop there, please. That's enough.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I thought that was better than Presidion analogy. Also, I'm going to delete my Twitter, because I can't afford to dumb myself down. I have to keep up with Juan half the time and we need to stay alert. But you're already hurting your eyes by looking at the screen. You're hurting your posture, it's already making you angry and it also can get you fired.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So there's a lot of inherent risk. It's like going to a baseball game.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, you can hit me.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Do you think, Katie, that Twitter helps at all for like enhancing a reputation?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well, a reputation? I think it can help depending on the way that you use it for brands to increase their reputation or to use it in a certain way. It's a tool, right. So if you use it bad way, it's a tool, it is bad. If you use it in a good way, it can be beneficial. I think the reason why they're saying that it substantially undermines your intelligence is because it requires a knee-jerk reaction to information, so you're not really diving in and thinking about the consequences of what you're responding to, it's emotional. People are saying things that they wouldn't say to you in person, they'll say it online. So, I think, just like anything else, it's a tool, can be used for good or bad.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So this study, Juan, basically it said that it - Twitter reduced performance on the test by about 25 to 40 percent of standard deviation from the average result.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, and I think, again, I think we're all in agreement here. I think that you have less likelihood to really think about what's in front of you. You're skimming. You're having quick emotional reactions, as Jesse said. And to me, a lot of this has to do with people who are distracted or lonely. And so you're just looking at Twitter, it's just something like to eat up your time to make you feel connected. And this is the primary illusion of social media in our age. I think that it makes you feel like you're really connected to what's going on, what's happening. In fact, you are more disconnected from what's going on. You're not engaged with real people. You're not engaged with real ideas, the challenge the way you think and what you're saying. You get locked into your bubble - maybe even more than a bubble, it's like a jail cell, because you're - on Twitter you're following people who oftentimes are of like mine. And I don't think that helps you to grow or to think differently or to come to an insight.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They said that, Greg, that the decline was sharpest among higher achieving students, including women. Do you believe that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So it's sexist. Twitter is sexist.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There you go, now we can delete it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But - yes. But to Juan's point, it's an illusion of social interaction that replaces real interaction. So it's actually - what do you call that when it's like a double - it's a double cost? It's like you're wasting time, but you're also losing something. There's a word for that.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: The opportunity cost.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Opportunity cost.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH

utterances.utterance: That's very good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. Politics can ruin anything - a dinner party, a holiday meal, California. Politics sucks, especially when it sneaks into places where it shouldn't be. Now politics can be helpful for it's a method to debate ideas, rather than pickup clubs and beat each other to death. All the energy once reserved for violence gets detoured into arguments, it's ugly but necessary. But decades ago our reliance on politics got out of hand, when the Left announced that the political was now personal and vice versa. Now politics rears its ugly face at football games and superhero movies and award shows and we're sick of it, which is why “The Five” teamed up with country music star John Rich to write a song with one piece of advice "Shut Up About Politics", because politics is only great if you keep it in its box, separate from all the other fun stuff in life. Politics is great in “The Five,” but not at the baseball game, so "Shut Up About Politics". It may be the greatest political song ever made, because we're hoping it will be the last political song ever made. So John you're here.
